questions.text:
An alcoholic man is admitted to a rehabilitation center for alcohol deaddiction. After three days, he develops visual hallucinations. His vital signs are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Pulse rate: 124 bpm
Blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg
Temperature: 101ºF
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an alcohol-dependent patient with tactile hallucinations, tachycardia, hypertension and fever following alcohol withdrawal indicates a likely diagnosis of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs within a week of a person stopping or reducing the intake of alcohol. Acute infection, hepatitis, and pancreatitis predispose a person in withdrawal to develop delirium tremens. Clinically, patients present with confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. Visual or tactile hallucinations are also seen, along with features of autonomic hyperactivity like tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever, insomnia, and hypertension. 

Delirium tremend is managed with benzodiazepines such as lorazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours). It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Wernicke encephalopathy is an acute encephalopathy caused due to thiamine deficiency in alcohol-dependent patients who tend to have micronutrient deficiencies. Patients present with a characteristic triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and global confusion. Treatment includes immediate administration of a high dose of 500 mg intravenous thiamine.

Option B: Korsakoff psychosis is an amnestic syndrome that occurs due to thiamine deficiency in alcohol-dependent patients. The clinical features include impairment of memory, confabulations, and disordered temporal sequencing. Treatment includes 100 mg of oral thiamine daily for 3-12 months.

Option D: In alcohol intoxication, there is a history of recent ingestion of alcohol. Patients present with slurred speech, incoordination, unsteady gait, and nystagmus. Impairments in attention and memory are also seen.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the physician's office with a history of a new nodule in the neck noted 2 months ago. The patient has a family history of thyroid cancer. Histopathology of the nodule shows the following finding. This patient must be screened for mutations in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathology showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma is characteristic of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Patients with MTC must be screened for RET point mutations so as to distinguish sporadic from familial disease. 

Medullary thyroid cancer(MTC) - 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland. Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, familial MTC is seen in MEN2A and MEN2B.

Clinical features - Commonly present as a solitary thyroid nodule. It can present with aerodigestive symptoms such as dysphagia or hoarseness. Lymph node involvement may be seen in some cases.

Diagnosis - Elevated CEA and calcitonin are commonly seen. USG findings may reveal signs of malignancy such as microcalcifications and hypoechoic lesions.

All new patients diagnosed with MTC should be screened for RET point mutations, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: What is the best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of a Ryle's tube?
questions.solution:
The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube (RT) is sitting with neck flexion. The described position helps in directing the RT towards the esophagus and also prevents it from coiling in the oropharynx or entering the trachea.

RT, also known as nasogastric (NG) tube, measures 120-125 cm. It has 4 markings at 40cm (cardia), 50cm (body), 60cm (pylorus), and 70 cm (duodenum) to indicate the approximate position after the placement.

Indications for NG tube:

  • Feeding in patients with dysphagia, decreased appetite, or those who are nil per os (NPO) for medical or surgical reasons.
  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome 
  • Bowel irrigation

The absolute contraindications for an NG tube are severe midface trauma, recent nasal surgery, and basilar skull fractures

Steps for the correct insertion of RT in an adult:

  1. Examination of the patient’s nostril for any anatomical abnormalities and then instillation with 10 ml of 1% lignocaine 
  2. NEX method is used to measure the length of the RT:  Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend the tube to the earlobe, and then to the xiphisternum.
  3. The patient is asked to sit upright with partial neck flexion. The tip of the Ryle’s tube is lubricated and passed along the floor of the nasal passage until a resistance is felt(corresponds to nasopharynx)
  4. The patient is subsequently asked to swallow water to guide the tube through the esophagus into the stomach until the marked length (based on the NEX method).
  5. NG tube is finally taped to secure it in place.


Confirmation of the correct position is done by:

  1. Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  2. X-ray chest to locate the lead markers
  3. Aspiration of contents and subsequently confirming gastric origin (pH <6 indicates gastric placement)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was scheduled for left frontal craniotomy and excision of a meningioma. After induction of anesthesia, a sudden brief dip in CO2 during the expiratory plateau phase on the capnograph was noticed. Which among the following are likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: History of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity
Obvious inspiratory efforts by the patient

questions.solution:
A sudden brief dip in CO2 during the expiratory plateau phase of the capnograph is known as the curare notch, seen in spontaneous breathing during mechanical ventilation. Obvious inspiratory efforts by the patient will be seen.

The patient's inspiratory effort causes some fresh gas to be sucked into the capnometer, resulting in a lower carbon dioxide concentration and a notch.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Other options:

Option A- Breath sounds in the epigastrium are a sign of oesophageal intubation. Endotracheal intubation is characterized by the absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Option B- In the capnograph of a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, there is no plateau before the next inspiration with an increased upslope of phase III. Seen in bronchospasm (asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), or if the endotracheal tube or breathing circuit is partially obstructed. 

Option D- A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity suggests malignant hyperthermia. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.
 

 

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days. Examination reveals a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate. His chest X-ray showed subglottic narrowing appearing like a steeple. Which among the following is not indicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever, and increased respiratory rate and an X-ray showing subglottic narrowing appearing like a steeple is suggestive of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis). Parenteral cefotaxime is not indicated in its treatment.

The median age for laryngotracheobronchitis is 3 months to 5 years. It is caused due to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions. Patients present with low-grade fever,  barking cough, hoarseness of voice, and inspiratory stridor. 

The image below shows a steeple sign, seen in croup.

Treatment of croup involves:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization - It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption from the interstitial space and reduction of edema. The indications for the administration of nebulized epinephrine are:
    • moderate to severe stridor at rest
    • the possible need for intubation
    • respiratory distress
    • hypoxia
  • Oral dexamethasone - Indicated in all the grades of croup. Corticosteroids reduce laryngeal edema through their anti-inflammatory action. IM dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equal clinical effect. Corticosteroids should not be administered to children with varicella or tuberculosis as they may worsen the disease.
  • A helium-oxygen mixture (heliox) may be considered for severe croup when intubation is being considered. Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

Most children that have croup can be managed safely at home. Indications for hospitalization:

  • Progressive stridor
  • Severe stridor at rest
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypoxia
  • Cyanosis
  • Depressed mental status
  • Poor oral intake
  • Need for reliable observation

NOTE:

As the duration of action of racemic epinephrine is only less than 2 hours, it is mandatory to place the patient on observation for 2-3 hours to watch for the reappearance of symptoms. The patient can be discharged home if he has:

  • No stridor at rest
  • Normal air entry
  • Normal O2 saturation
  • Normal level of consciousness
  • Received steroids

questions.text: A 40-year-old sexually active, otherwise healthy man presented with a 3-month history of painless ulcers in the pubic area and over the penis. He mentioned that they were initially nodules that progressed to red ulcerated lesions over the last 1 month. Physical examination revealed multiple beefy-red nontender, round ulcers of various sizes around the pubic area and on the penis. The base of the ulcers shows granulation tissue that bleeds on touch. Direct microscopy appears as shown in the image below. Identify the incorrect statement about the diagnosis of this condition.

choices.text: Smears can be examined by direct microscopy with the Giemsa stain
Smears can be examined by direct microscopy with the Wright's stain
Granulation tissue crushed and spread between two slides can be used for microscopy.
The organism cannot be cultured in vitro.

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette described is Granuloma inguinale (donovanosis). It is a chronic, progressive sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. Klebsiella granulomatis is difficult to culture but can be grown on egg yolk medium and on modified Levinthal's agar.

While collecting a sample for smear, the lesion should first be cleaned with a dry cotton swab to remove debris. Care should be taken not to disrupt any small blood vessels, to minimize bleeding. If donovanosis is suspected clinically, the swab should always be obtained before another testing to maximize tissue collections.

Granulation tissue can be obtained by using either forceps or scalpel and then crushed between two slides as an alternative method to obtaining a smear.

On direct microscopy, Donovan bodies are seen inside large, mononuclear cells (pund cells) as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies. They can have a characteristic safety pin appearance due to bipolar staining of the chromatin material. When these cyst structures rupture, infectious organisms are released. The stains commonly used are the Giemsa stain and the Wright stain. Klebsiella granulomatis is difficult to culture but can be grown on egg yolk medium and on modified Levinthal's agar.

Histopathological examination shows chronic inflammation with plasma cells and neutrophil infiltration. Epithelial changes like ulceration, microabscesses, and elongation of rete ridges are seen.

The image below shows round, beefy-red ulcers with granulation tissue on the penis and pubic area - seen in granuloma inguinale.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents to the OPD with complaints that her periods have not started, but she has been experiencing lower abdominal pain every month. She also complains of difficulty in passing urine. On examination, she has normal female secondary sexual characteristics, a midline hypogastric lump in the abdomen, and a bluish bulging membrane at the introitus. Identify the incorrect statement(s) about the treatment of this condition.
  1. A cruciate incision is made anteroposteriorly from 10 to 4 and from 2 to 8 o’clock positions
  2. Vaginal irrigation is undertaken following the procedure.
  3. Simple needle aspiration is an alternate method of treatment.
  4. Thorough intraoperative evaluation of upper vagina, cervix and uterus should be done during the procedure
  5. Running interlocking suture of the cut edges is avoided.
questions.solution:
The condition described is imperforate hymen and the incorrect statements about the treatment of the condition are 3 and 4. Simple needle aspiration of the hematocolpos and evaluation of the uterus, cervix and/or the upper vagina are avoided as they may increase the risk of infection and perforation respectively.

The hymen generally perforates during fetal life, creating a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum. Imperforate hymen is due to the failure of the inferior end of the vaginal plate to canalize. Endometrial blood collects leading to the formation of hematocolpos. Retrograde menstruation may lead to the development of endometriosis.

Treatment:

A simple cruciate incision of the hymen made anteroposteriorly from 10-4 and 2-8 o’clock positions allow the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, leading to normal reproductive function. The hymeneal leaflets are sharply trimmed, but not excised too closely to the vaginal epithelium to prevent scarring. The vagina is then irrigated with a sterile saline solution. Cut edges are then sutured with interrupted stitches.  A running interlocking suture line is avoided as it might lead to narrowing of the introitus.

Laparoscopy is often performed to exclude endometriosis. However, intraoperative manipulation or evaluation of the upper vagina, cervix, or uterine cavity is avoided. This is to reduce the risk of perforation, as the hematocolpos might have significantly thinned the uterine walls.

Needle aspiration of a hematocolpos should be avoided because it may seed the retained blood with bacteria and increase infection risks. Moreover, the hematocolpos may recur as a result of inadequate drainage.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of swollen fingers, heartburn, and occasional joint pains. On examination, the skin over her hands is shiny, taut, and thickened with non-pitting edema. Distal skin creases are absent. Movement of the hand is limited and there appears to be some muscle weakness. Autoantibody assays showed the presence of topoisomerase I antibodies and Anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies. Which among the following features are less commonly seen in this variant of the disease?
  1. Esophageal involvement
  2. Skin involvement
  3. Scleroderma renal crisis
  4. Ischemic ulcers on digits
  5. Interstitial lung disease
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with positive ANA antibodies, topoisomerase I antibodies, and Anti-RNA polymerase I and III antibodies is diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Esophageal involvement and ischemic ulcers on digits are less commonly seen in this variety of the disease. 

Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder of connective tissue resulting in fibrosis of the skin, internal organs, and vasculature. It is characterized by Raynaud’s phenomenon, ischemia of the digits, sclerodactyly, and cardiac, lung, gut, and renal disease. The peak age of onset is between the fourth and fifth decades of life.

It is divided into:

  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (30% of cases) - poor prognosis
  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (70% of cases)

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
  • Anti-RNA polymerase I and III antibodies - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
  • Anti centromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: A 4-week old baby diagnosed with biliary atresia was posted for Kasai's procedure. After the surgery, the child was well for a brief period, but the condition gradually deteriorated, progressing to a failure to thrive. To enter the waiting list for a hepatic transplant, the Paediatric End-stage Liver Disease (PELD) score is to be calculated. Which of the following investigations is not required for the calculation of this score?
questions.solution:
Serum creatinine is used in the Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) scoring but is not required for Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) scoring. Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in the pediatric age group, followed by metabolic and inborn disorders, autoimmune and familial cholestatic disorders, and acute hepatic necrosis.

The PELD model for children under 12 years of age, includes both clinical and biochemical factors. It is predictive of disease severity and waiting list mortality in pediatric patients. The PELD score is calculated using the following variables:

  • Albumin (g/dl)
  • Bilirubin (mg/dl)
  • INR (International normalized ratio)
  • Growth failure (based on gender, height, and weight)
  • Age at listing

The Child-Pugh score is a predictor of survival and complications of cirrhosis, such as bleeding from varices and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. It was earlier used to provide standard criteria for listing a patient as a candidate for liver transplantation (Child-Pugh class B) but it has been replaced by the Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) and Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) models for all patients with chronic liver disease.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

 

Related Pearl: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

The Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) score was originally developed to evaluate the risk of portocaval shunt procedures performed for portal hypertension. It is also useful in predicting the surgical risks of other intra-abdominal operations performed in cirrhotic patients.

questions.text:
The following three MR images of the head taken in the sagittal plane are given to you. Match the image to the MR imaging technique used.
  1. T1 weighted
  2. T2 weighted
  3. STIR
  4. FLAIR
questions.solution:
Image 1 - T2 weighted MRI, image 2 - T1 weighted MRI, and image 3 is a STIR MRI.

By altering the sequence of pulses and the scanning parameters, different properties of the tissue can be assessed. These properties are referred to as the weighting of the scan. T1-weighted images and T2-weighted images are two types of imaging sequences with differences in image contrast.

T1 weighted images:

  • Fluid appears dark (blood, edema, CSF)
  • Fat appears white

T2 weighted images:

  • Fluid appears white 
  • Fat appears dark

STIR- Short tau inversion recovery or short TI inversion recovery

  • Inversion recovery time is short and is used to null signal from fat.
  • Fat appears dark
  • Highly sensitive to detect musculoskeletal disease, degenerative changes, MS lesions, and vertebral metastasis
  • More prone to motion artifacts. Therefore not used in the imaging of the thoracic spine

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery):

  • It is a T2 weighted sequence with a long inversion recovery time that suppresses signals from the fluid.
  • Fluid appears dark
  • Fat appears dark
  • Motion artifacts in CSF are removed

 

Note: CT can be differentiated from MRI depending on the appearance of bone. Bones appear white on CT, whereas, they appear dark on MRI.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child is brought into the emergency room after his elder sibling while playing with the child pulled up the child by holding the childs's hands. The child is now crying, does not use her arm, and does not let anybody touch it. Which of the following statements are true regarding the underlying condition in this patient?
  1. Occurs due to subluxation of the annular ligament over the radial head.
  2. Children commonly present with the elbow fully flexed and the forearm supinated.
  3. X-ray is mandatory for confirming the diagnosis in all patients.
  4. Reduction may be achieved through the hyperpronation technique.
  5. Forearm flexion and supination can be used to achieve a reduction.
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is pulled elbow/ Nursemaid's elbow and radial head subluxations(RHS) is the cause here. The history of lifting the child by the forearm and later the child refusing to let anyone touch her hand is pointing towards the diagnosis of the pulled elbow. 

The following statements are true regarding pulled elbow

1 - Occurs due to subluxation of the annular ligament over the radial head.
2 - Children commonly present with the elbow extended or slightly flexed(NOT fully flexed) and the forearm pronated(NOT supinated).
3 - X-ray is not necessary for diagnosis in all patients. Specific conditions where it is required are mentioned below.
4 - Reduction may be achieved through the hyperpronation technique. 
5 - Forearm flexion and supination can be used to achieve a reduction.

The mechanism underlying this deformity is the subluxation of the annular ligament over the radial head. Characteristically the child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.

Diagnosis is clinical and X-ray is needed only if there is confusion.
X-ray is required only in patients who do not have a history of a "pull injury" or who have equivocal physical examination findings, indications for plain radiographs include:

- <5 years of age:

  • Age <6 months without a history of having the arm pulled or caught underneath the body when rolling over 
  • A concerning mechanism of injury (eg, direct blow or high-force injury)
  • A physical examination that demonstrates swelling beyond the anterolateral aspect of the radial head
  • Focal bony tenderness over the proximal ulna or distal humerus
  • Any bony deformity
  • Inability to successfully reduce a presumed RHS 

 

- ≥5 years of age:

  • RHS is uncommon at this age. Unless there is a classic mechanism of an arm pull and a physical examination consistent with the diagnosis, most children with pain and immobility of the arm warrant radiographs.

Treatment is achieved with the hyperpronation technique or by forearm flexion and supination.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow

Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action

questions.text: A 2-week old, healthy baby was brought with a rash on his trunk. It appeared as crops of small clear vesicles without any signs of inflammation, suggestive of miliaria crystallina. Identify the layer of skin in which the blockage of eccrine glands occurs.
questions.solution:
In miliaria crystallina, the obstruction of the eccrine sweat duct occurs at the stratum corneum (layer A), and hence the resultant vesicle that contains clear fluid is subcorneal in location.

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat glands. The three forms of miliaria - miliaria crystallina, miliaria rubra, and miliaria profunda differ from each other due to the different levels at which occlusion occurs.

The level of blockade/disruption in miliaria is:

Miliaria crystallina Stratum corneum
Miliaria profunda At or below Dermoepidermal junction

 

The layers of the epidermis are shown in the image given below.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: Which of the following strains of Chlamydia are implicated in causing trachoma?
questions.solution:
Serotypes A, B, and C are implicated in the development of trachoma, a form of chronic conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

Trachoma is considered a major cause of blindness in the developing world. It is endemic in nature, mostly affecting children with a female preponderance. The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

Stage 1: Incipient 

  • Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.

Stage 2: Established

  • Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring

Stage 3: Cicatrizing

  • Scarring along with active infection

Stage 4: Healed

  • Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

Other Options:

Options A and D - Serotypes L1-L3 are implicated in lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option B - Serotypes D-K are implicated in the development of acute inclusion conjunctivitis, genital ulcers, and infantile pneumonia. Acute inclusion conjunctivitis presents with follicular and papillary hypertrophy, which is greater in the lower eyelid, and associated with moderately abundant exudate that is principally composed of neutrophils.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl presents with severe pain in the left iliac fossa. On palpation, a 4x4cm tender mass is felt. Laparotomy is performed and pathological examination reveals a cystic cavity filled with teeth, sebaceous material, cartilage, bone, and glandular tissue. Which of the following statements are false about the mass?
  1. Frequently arise in association with mucinous cystadenomas
  2. Constitute 5-10% of cystic ovarian tumours
  3. The lining of the tumour is always squamous epithelium
  4. Multilocular cysts are never seen
  5. It occurs bilaterally in 12-15% of the cases
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests the tumor is a dermoid cyst, which had undergone torsion. Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect.

The lining of the dermoid cyst, while usually squamous epithelium, it can also be columnar or transitional epithelium. Though the cysts are usually unilocular with a smooth surface, they can also be multilocular.

Dermoid Cysts

  • 5-10% of all cystic ovarian tumors
  • Bilateral in 12-15% cases 
  • Usually Unilocular with a smooth surface, but can also be multilocular
  • Mature teratoma 
  • Contains tissue arising from all 3 germ layers
  • Teeth, bone, and hair arise from embryonic node 
  • Sebaceous material common 
  • Wall usually squamous epithelium, can be formed by other epithelium too 
  • About 40% of dermoid cysts are found in conjunction with mucinous cystadenomas
  • Can undergo torsion and present as acute abdomen
  • Multiple dermoids can coexist in a single ovary 
  • Can be extra-ovarian- lumbar, parasacral, uterovesical pouch, rectovaginal septum

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promotes bone formation?
questions.solution:
Teriparatide increases bone formation especially when given in low doses and intermittently.
Teriparatide is a recombinant preparation of parathyroid hormone.

The pharmacologic activity of teriparatide, which is similar to the physiologic activity of PTH, includes stimulating osteoblast function, increasing gastrointestinal calcium absorption, and increasing renal tubular reabsorption of calcium.

Although it may be more effective than bisphosphonates and estrogen, it has to be administered subcutaneously every day. Hence it is indicated mostly in severe osteoporosis.

Teriparatide increases the risk of osteosarcoma and it is contraindicated in conditions that cause high risk of osteosarcoma such as:

  • Paget disease
  • Prior h/o of radiotherapy
  • Young adults with open epiphysis
  • Unexplained elevated ALP
  • Hypercalcemia

Option A: Calcitonin decreases bone resorption.

Option B: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator, which decreases bone resorption. It is used to prevent and treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

Option C: Bisphosphonates like alendronate and etidronate decrease bone resorption.

choices.text: It is predominantly absorbed from the duodenum
Its uptake is mediated by divalent metal transporter type 2

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly woman presenting with easy fatiguability with pallor and laboratory features of decreased hemoglobin, serum iron, transferrin saturation, serum ferritin, and increased TIBC (total iron binding capacity), suggest iron-deficiency anemia. Iron is predominantly absorbed from the duodenum.

Iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in its absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the enterocyte, the ferric form is converted to the ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1).

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin. The iron in plasma is transported to the required tissues by the protein transferrin. 

Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of the electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed. Several factors can increase or decrease iron absorption. Ascorbic acid increases iron absorption whereas, phytates (in bran, oats, rye fiber), polyphenols (in tea), calcium, and soy protein decrease its absorption.

Therefore, a patient with anemia must be advised to consume red meat and oranges/lemons and to avoid coffee, tea, and calcium tablets while taking iron tablets.

questions.text: A surgeon applies a very tight plaster cast on patient’s leg and asks the patient to inform if he develops any numbness. The patient develops numbness but does not inform the doctor immediately. Next day, when the patient informs the doctor, the doctor says he is too busy to remove the cast. After a few days, the patient develops a permanent injury. The doctor is held guilty under:
questions.solution:
This is a case of last clear chance doctrine and the doctor is held guilty.

In this case:

  • The doctor showed negligence by applying tight plaster cast, however, gave proper instructions to the patient.
  • The patient has neglected by not informing the doctor immediately after he developed numbness.
  • When the patient informed the doctor the next day, the doctor still had a chance to remove the cast and prevent permanent injury. But the doctor again neglected and thus missed the last clear chance.

So, the doctor cannot plead for contributory negligence and will be held guilty under the last clear chance doctrine.

Other options:

Option D: Medical maloccurrence is a defence against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: In a primary health center, a nurse asks you about using a polio vaccine vial which has not crossed its expiry date. You look at the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) and tell her that it can be used. What did the VVM most likely show?

choices.text: Inner square white, outer circle blue
Inner square blue, outer circle white
Outer square white, inner circle blue
Outer square blue, inner circle white

questions.solution:
The vaccine vial monitor has most likely showed inner square white and outer circle blue.

The standard polio vaccine vial monitor has a colour monitor or labels on the vaccine bottles. The label has an inner white square and an outer blue circle.

It can be used if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle. When the colour of the inner square becomes that of the circle, it means that the vaccine has been exposed to a higher temperature and it cannot be used. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.
